intro: Amphithalea micrantha, commonly known as the narrow-leaved sandmat, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of southern Africa. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in sandy or rocky soils and is adapted to withstand drought conditions. Its flowers are usually white or pale green, and it produces small, dry fruits known as schizocarps. Amphithalea micrantha is often found in disturbed habitats and is considered a pioneer species in ecological succession.
